lines.text:
[Opening credits narration]
I thought I was a big shot. Big money, big house, big car...I thought I held all the cards. I thought I could pick the winner every time, I thought I could smell it...but the whole thing was built on garbage. I treated my wife badly and I knew it and I didn't stop and one day she walked. She took my daughter with her. I started gambling big time, crazy stuff, long shot stuff. I turned into the kind of man that I'd grown up hating. Making the big bucks and being made a partner wasn't enough to buy that off. I'm just kinda starting from scratch, trying to keep things low pressure.
[Jack Shannon tries to talk Wilmer Slade out of taking his entire payment]
Then you should understand that a payment of this size is going to make Mr. Testa very upset.
Why do I sense an oncoming assault on logic?
Paulie, I'm beginning to think you wanted to get arrested. Why?
Why? To publicize my plight!
Ah, Paulie, don't try saying them words unless your teeth are in good!
You don't have to heap more guilt on me. I'm doing just fine on my own.
What do you think of terrarium blue?
Good beat, easy to dance to, could herald the return of disco. What are you talking about?
Yo, Shannon! I've been freezing my posterior regions waiting for you. That your daughter?
You been tailing me, Wilmer?
I didn't want to interrupt a family situation.
Very tactful of you.
You want something out of me.
I thought you'd never ask. Leo! Uh, have you ever done any child custody work?
I get the feeling I'm about to.
You're a good father, you're a good lawyer, and if you paid me on a regular basis, you'd be a good boss.
Wouldn't want to be perfect.
If I had paper from your office, it would carry some weight--
Shannon, forget it, no. The boat has sailed. Now, if you bleed these people, I'll have you up on ethics.
Well, there goes another night's sleep.
I was willing to let my marriage fall apart, and my job slide...all sorts of awful stuff. But I could never bring myself to cheat at cards, even when it would have saved my tail.
I used to dance topless for guys, but wouldn't let 'em buy me a drink.
Some joke, huh?
Listen, I'm sorry about that check, man.
Well, you conned me about your record. Why not the check?
Look, I'm not like that. No, I mean it. You ever gamble?
Now and then.

All right. Well, you ever find yourself in a spot where the stakes are ten times higher than what you got in your pocket? You just gotta play out the hand, and hope you win. That's what my life is like now, man.
You did the right thing, boss.
Maybe. Did something I thought I'd never stoop to.
Going around the law?
Cheated at cards.
[Wilmer informs Jack that a convict with a grudge has put a price on Jack's head.]
Where would he get that kind of money?
Shannon, all due respect, uh, what makes you think you're worth all "that kind of money?"
Oh. Glad you're here to protect me from overweening pride.
"Overweening?"
Thought you'd like that.
You think I'm proud of you? Well, I ain't! Not anymore.

You were proud of me for all the wrong reasons. For being the kind of big shot you brought me up to hate. Well, you fell into a bottle, Dad, and I crawled up to a card game! I guess neither of us got much to be proud of, huh?!
I'm gonna make like a leper and intercept any cash that may flow your way until I have the renumeration in hand.
What's that mean in English?
Whither thou goest, I shall go. Until I get at least a thousand in my pocket.
All right, let's get going.
Lay on, MacDuff.
[Shannon stares at him.]
Shakespeare. I find vocabulary studies so limiting.
You Mr. Shannon?
Yeah.

[hands Shannon a large envelope]
This from Kingston. He told me to say it's even now, and that he ain't playin' no more poker with you.
Not exactly playing with a strong hand.
It ain't the hand, Jackie-boy. It's the player.
So what'd you get?
You'd be proud of me. I milked him for two hundred dollars.
Hey! Everybody's entitled to get paid. Now don't seem too personal. I mean, any other lawyer would milk harder and care less.

[holds out his hand]
Your good luck is mine.
Awwww...
